questions.text:
A 26-year-old man comes to the physician with a 4-day history of fever and malaise followed by the onset of severe joint pain yesterday. This morning, his body felt unusually stiff. He works as a social media expert and went to Puerto Rico on a business trip 10 days ago. He has no personal or family history of serious illness. He does not smoke and sometimes drinks alcohol socially after work. He is in a polyamorous relationship and reports that he was sexually active with one female partner during the business trip; he uses condoms. He appears lethargic but is alert and oriented. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 64/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 123/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows tender deltoid muscles bilaterally as well as tenderness in proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, radiocarpal joints, and tarsophalangeal joints bilaterally. The left first metatarsophalangeal joint is swollen with no erythema or tenderness. A diffuse nonpruritic maculopapular rash is visible. Laboratory studies show:


Hematocrit
41%


Leukocyte count
3600/mm3


Segmented neutrophils
62%


Eosinophils
2%


Lymphocytes
20%


Monocytes
6%


Platelet count
113,000/mm3


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
2 mm/h


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated Lyme disease can cause fever, malaise, myalgia, diffuse rash, and arthralgia. However, this condition usually causes migratory arthralgia rather than symmetric polyarthralgia and generally affects large joints such as the knees and elbows. In addition, disseminated Lyme disease usually manifests with multiple erythema migrans lesions that spread from a single erythema migrans lesion around the bite site rather than the diffuse maculopapular rash seen here.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's acute onset of fever, malaise, myalgia, symmetric polyarthralgia affecting distal joints, morning stiffness, and maculopapular rash in combination with lymphopenia and thrombocytopenia after traveling to Puerto Rico are suggestive of Chikungunya virus infection. This condition most commonly occurs in tropical and subtropical regions and is transmitted via Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquito bites; the incubation period ranges from 1 to 14 days (usually 3 to 7 days). The diagnosis is confirmed via RT-PCR or serology. Treatment is supportive. Although many patients fully recover, some develop chronic arthritis, which can be severe and often incapacitating, as a complication of Chikungunya virus infection.

Because infections with Chikungunya virus, Dengue virus, and Zika virus can have similar clinical presentations, including arthralgia, fever, and a diffuse maculopapular rash, a single PCR that simultaneously tests for all three viruses should be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) can occur in sexually active young adults and cause polyarthralgia (gonococcal arthritis), fever, malaise, and a rash. However, the polyarthralgia seen in DGI is typically asymmetric and migratory, unlike the symmetric, nonmigratory polyarthralgia in this patient, and the rash is usually vesicular or pustular (possibly with a necrotic or hemorrhagic center) rather than maculopapular. Moreover, leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are elevated in most cases. Furthermore, this patient uses condoms, making a sexually transmitted infection such as DGI unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis can cause acute-onset fever and severe joint pain with swelling. However, a single large joint rather than multiple distal joints is usually affected; polyarticular involvement is rare and tends to occur in patients with preexisting joint diseases (e.g., rheumatoid arthritis, SLE) or as a result of hematogenous dissemination (e.g., sepsis, infective endocarditis), neither of which this patient has signs of. Moreover, septic arthritis does not cause diffuse myalgias, a maculopapular rash, early morning stiffness, leukopenia, or thrombocytopenia. Instead, patients with septic arthritis usually have a severe restriction of movement in the affected joint and nonspecific elevations of WBC and erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

E) INCORRECT:

Malaria is common in tropical and subtropical regions including Puerto Rico. This condition is transmitted via mosquito bite and causes fever, malaise, myalgias, arthralgias, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia. However, malaria does not cause a diffuse maculopapular rash. In addition, patients with malaria usually present with periodic fever spikes, whereas this patient's fever has been constant over the last 4 days.

F) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) causes morning stiffness and symmetric polyarthralgia, primarily affects the proximal interphalangeal joints and metacarpophalangeal joints, and is often preceded by a prodrome of constitutional symptoms (i.e., fever, malaise, myalgia). However, RA typically develops insidiously; forms of RA that arise acutely (e.g., palindromic rheumatism, late-onset RA) are less common. Moreover, rheumatoid nodules, neutrophilic dermatoses, and features of cutaneous vasculitis (e.g., petechiae, skin ulcers) rather than a maculopapular rash are the typical dermatological manifestations of RA. Furthermore, during a flare of RA, patients usually have an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate and tend to develop thrombocytosis and/or mild leukocytosis. Leukopenia, which is seen here, only occurs in RA as a result of immunosuppressive treatment or Felty syndrome, a rare complication.

G) INCORRECT:

Gout flares can cause acute-onset joint pain and swelling and most commonly affect the distal small joints, especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint, which is swollen in this patient. However, gout attacks usually only affect a single joint; polyarticular involvement and extra-articular symptoms such as fever and muscle tenderness are less common. Moreover, classic gout attacks peak at night 12–24 hours after an inciting event (e.g., heavy drinking), manifest with excruciating pain and cardinal signs of inflammation as well as an elevated WBC and erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and are not associated with a rash.
questions.hint: This patient's condition is transmitted via mosquito bite.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a rash on her back that developed 4 days ago. Two weeks ago, she returned from a hiking trip in California and immediately had a headache and fever that lasted 5 days. She has no other history of serious illness and takes no other medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears tired. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 19/min. Examination shows a maculopapular rash on the patient's upper back and posterior arms. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Initial complete blood count and serum studies are normal. Serologic screening for infectious diseases reveals positive West Nile virus-specific IgM antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely outcome of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Memory impairment is a potential long-term sequela of patients with neuroinvasive disease due to West Nile virus (WNV) infection. However, neuroinvasive disease is only seen in up to 1% of patients infected with WNV and is more common in older individuals, in immunocompromised, or in those with comorbidities (e.g., hypertension, diabetes mellitus).

B) INCORRECT:

Neuroinvasive disease resulting in paralysis is a very rare sequela of West Nile virus infection. The paralysis is typically flaccid, not spastic, and occurs due to damage to anterior horn cells in the spinal cord.

C) INCORRECT:

Meningoencephalitis is a form of neuroinvasive disease, which can develop following West Nile virus infection. However, it is only seen in up to 1% of patients and is more common in older individuals, in immunocompromised, or in those with comorbidities (e.g., hypertension, diabetes mellitus). While it is good to know potential outcomes, it is important for exam questions to focus on which one is “most likely.”

D) INCORRECT:

Hemorrhagic fever can occur following infection with West Nile virus and, in severe cases, may lead to multiorgan failure and death. However, fatal hemorrhagic fever is an extremely rare complication that is more commonly seen in patients infected with yellow fever or dengue fever.

E) CORRECT:

West Nile virus (WNV) is the most common cause of arboviral-acquired disease in the US. Although WNV infection is asymptomatic in the majority of patients (approx. 80%), it can lead to West Nile fever, a self-limiting disease that typically lasts 3–10 days and manifests with fever, headaches, and a transient maculopapular rash on the trunks and extremities, as seen here. In up to 1% of patients, WNV infection can lead to a neuroinvasive disease that manifests with fever and meningitis, encephalitis, or acute flaccid paralysis. Risk factors for neuroinvasive disease include age > 60 years, immunosuppression, or other comorbidities (e.g., hypertension, diabetes mellitus). Because the condition is usually self-limiting, treatment is supportive.

While it is good to be aware of all potential outcomes of a condition, it is important to know which ones are “most likely” as some exam questions may focus only on these more realistic clinical scenarios.
questions.hint: On exam questions, it is important to only concentrate on which one is “most likely” and not get distracted by the several options that may be potential outcomes.

questions.text:
An 83-year-old woman with a history of hypertension is brought to the emergency department after she was found at home, confused and unable to get out of bed. Approximately 2 weeks ago, she attended a picnic with her church group in a wooded area and ate some undercooked barbecued fish and meat. A few days later, she developed a fever, headache, and joint pains. She became increasingly weak and needed to use a walker.
On physical examination, her temperature is 38.8°C, her heart rate is 98 beats per minute, and her blood pressure is 145/87 mm Hg. She is disoriented and requires constant stimuli to stay alert. The rest of her neurological examination shows facial diplegia, diffuse weakness, and areflexia. No signs of meningismus or sensory deficits are noted. She is unable to walk.
She is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Laboratory examination of the cerebrospinal fluid yields the following results:



Patient value


Erythrocyte count (per mm3)
0



Leukocyte count (per mm3)
80 (lymphocytic predominance)


Protein (mg/dL)
70


Glucose (mg/dL)
68


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fever, altered mental status, and flaccid paralysis with areflexia in the absence of sensory findings are typical characteristics of West Nile virus encephalitis, a poliomyelitis-like illness. Testing of the cerebrospinal fluid typically shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis.

Most patients with West Nile virus infection remain asymptomatic; some develop a self-limited viral illness with headache, malaise, and myalgia. However, patients who are older than age 50 and those who are immunosuppressed are at increased risk for meningoencephalitis and neuroinvasive disease involving the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord.

Key learning point: Acute onset of fever, encephalitis, flaccid paralysis, and areflexia is a typical presentation of West Nile virus encephalitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome can also manifest with weakness, but it is not typically associated with pleocytosis, encephalitis, or fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Botulism, which results from the action of neurotoxin produced by Clostridium botulinum, can cause weakness that is typically bilateral descending in nature, with symmetric cranial-nerve neuropathies. However, confusion, fever, and pleocytosis are not seen.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the pork tapeworm Taenia solium in its larval stage. This organism is transmitted among humans primarily via the fecal-oral route, whereby eggs shed in the feces of a person with an active tapeworm infection are ingested by another person and then hatch into larvae that can penetrate the intestinal wall and reach a variety of tissues where they form cysts. Neurocysticercosis is characterized by seizures (in 80% of patients) and rarely involves the peripheral nerves. Patients are typically afebrile.

E) INCORRECT:

Scrombroid poisoning occurs from consuming inappropriately refrigerated or preserved fish, but it usually manifests as an allergic-type reaction (including flushing and urticaria) within an hour of consumption.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman in Texas presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of fever, headache, and myalgias. Three days ago, she developed confusion and difficulty with balance. Today, her daughter reports new-onset rhythmic jerking movements of both arms. The patient has hypertension and type 2 diabetes. Vital signs are BP, 142/88; P, 96; R, 18; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows altered mental status, neck stiffness, and bilateral upper extremity myoclonus. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain serum for West Nile virus IgM antibodies
Perform lumbar puncture with staining for acid-fast bacilli
Order brain MRI with and without contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient's clinical presentation and the 10-day duration make viral encephalitis more likely than bacterial meningitis. The bilateral upper extremity myoclonus is particularly characteristic of neuroinvasive West Nile virus fever. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are inappropriate without evidence of bacterial infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Empirical acyclovir is indicated if herpes simplex encephalitis is suspected. This patient's bilateral upper extremity myoclonus and the specific combination of risk factors (age > 60 years with hypertension and diabetes) make neuroinvasive West Nile virus fever more likely.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This clinical presentation of fever, headache, and myalgias progressing to altered mental status, neck stiffness, and bilateral upper extremity myoclonus in a patient with risk factors (age > 60 years, hypertension, diabetes) is highly suggestive of neuroinvasive West Nile virus fever. The 10-day symptom duration is optimal timing for serology testing, as MAC-ELISA for IgM antibodies should be performed after the 8th day of symptom onset and is the gold standard diagnostic test. The combination of epidemiological risk factors, clinical syndrome, and appropriate timing makes serology the most appropriate next step.

D) INCORRECT:

While lumbar puncture would show increased lymphocytes and proteins with normal glucose levels and can be analyzed for specific IgM antibodies, staining for acid-fast bacilli is only performed if tuberculous meningoencephalitis is suspected. The myalgia in combination with bilateral upper extremity myoclonus are not typical for tuberculous meningoencephalitis.

E) INCORRECT:

Brain MRI in neuroinvasive West Nile virus fever typically shows normal findings or nonspecific changes with increased signal intensity. MRI may be helpful to exclude other causes of altered mental status, but it cannot establish the specific viral etiology.
